summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ OIG Special Agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons Senior Officer Specialist (acting as an Activities Lieutenant) regarding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein. The interview focuses on the witness's duties, shift assignments, and knowledge of procedures at MCC New York on August 9-10, 2019, including counts, rounds, cellmate requirements, and the chain of command for information dissemination.

events.title: Witness's Shift as Activities Lieutenant
events.description: The witness worked her regular shift (8am-4pm) as Senior Officer Specialist in attorney conference, then overtime as Activities Lieutenant (4pm-10pm). She conducted a lieutenant round in the SHU between 5pm and 8pm and saw Epstein in attorney conference.

events.title: Removal of Epstein's Cellmate
events.description: Efren Reyes, Epstein's cellmate, was removed from the SHU (likely for court) around 8am and the MCC was notified around 1-2pm that he would not be returning, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

events.title: Psychology Email on Cellmate Requirement
events.description: Psychology staff sent an email to lieutenants stating Epstein was required to have a cellmate after coming off suicide watch/psych observation.

events.title: Epstein's Prior Suicide Attempt
events.description: Reference to an alleged suicide attempt by Jeffrey Epstein in July 2019, prior to his death.

locations: Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York
keyFacts: The witness, a BOP Senior Officer Specialist, was acting as an Activities Lieutenant on overtime from 4pm to 10pm on August 9, 2019, the night before Epstein's death.

The witness was unaware of the psychology email (dated July 30, 2019) mandating that Epstein have a cellmate at all times, and stated the operations lieutenant should have informed her of this requirement.

The witness described a breakdown in the chain of command regarding the cellmate requirement: if the operations lieutenant did not disseminate the information, line staff would not know, and it was not their responsibility to know.

The interview examines discrepancies in inmate count sheets for the SHU between the 4pm, 10pm, and midnight counts on August 9-10, 2019, suggesting possible improvised documentation or ghost counting.

The witness stated that in her opinion, honest mistakes were made by certain individuals regarding counts, rounds, and the cellmate requirement, and that counting inmates is the primary duty of correctional officers.
